definition:
A continuous map ${f:{X\rightarrow Y}}$ between path-connected based
topological spaces is said to be a [*weak homotopy equivalence*]{} if
for each $k\ge 1$ it induces an isomorphism
${f_*:{\pi_k(X)\rightarrow \pi_k(Y)}}$ between the $k$th homotopy
groups. $X$ and $Y$ are then said to be [*weakly homotopy
equivalent.*]{}

It is [*not*]{} enough for $\pi_k(X)$ to be isomorphic to $\pi_k(Y)$ for
all $k.$ The definition requires these isomorphisms to be induced by a
space-level map $f.$

More generally, two spaces $X$ and $Y$ are defined to be weakly homotopy
equivalent if there is a sequence of spaces and maps
$$X \to X_1 {\leftarrow}X_2 \to X_3 {\leftarrow}\cdots \to X_n {\leftarrow}Y$$
in which each map is a weak homotopy equivalence.
